parameters.source_text:
A case of payment for research A research project
focusing on speci c CSF enzyme levels in neurolog- fi
ical disease requires control measures. For this pur-
pose, healthy participants are required who are
willing to undergo lumbar puncture. Recruitment is
slow. The researchers have funding and propose to
pay each participant £800 in order to increase the
recruitment rate. The participants are properly
informed about the procedure and its risks and give
valid consent to take part in the research. However,
most would not have given consent were it not for
the £800.

data.vignette:
You are a neurologist running an IRB-approved study measuring CSF biomarkers to improve diagnosis in neurodegenerative disease. Your clinic patient is a 29-year-old with well-controlled migraines who is otherwise healthy. She asks about joining the study after seeing a flyer. Participation requires a lumbar puncture done in your procedure suite. You explain the process and the real risks, including severe post–lumbar puncture headache, bleeding, infection, and rare neurologic injury. The study budget allows an £800 payment per participant, and she says she would not consider the procedure without the money because she is behind on rent. She appears to understand the information and answers questions appropriately. Enrollment is slow, and the grant requires a minimum number of control samples within the next few weeks. Hospital policy and the IRB permit either paying this amount or declining to recruit her.

You must decide how to proceed.
data.choice_1: Enroll her and perform the lumbar puncture with the £800 payment.
data.choice_2: Decline to enroll her and do not perform the lumbar puncture.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften phrasing that makes the LP risks feel disproportionate or frames enrollment as primarily a funding problem. Keep concrete risks but balance by noting that in healthy volunteers LP is generally low-risk when performed by experienced staff; avoid implying either choice is medically superior. Replace “real risks” with “known risks,” and remove “rare neurologic injury” or qualify as “very uncommon.” Also avoid emphasizing “minimum number of control samples” as if scientific success justifies risk; state neutrally that “the study has a near-term enrollment deadline.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim nonessential details and add one missing ethical-relevant clinical detail. Remove: “well-controlled migraines” unless tied to increased risk of post-LP headache; if kept, explicitly state it may increase likelihood of post-LP headache to clarify stakes. Remove “after seeing a flyer” (decorative). Add: whether participation offers any direct clinical benefit (likely none) and confirm she is a healthy control/volunteer. Clarify whether she has alternative financial supports or coercion safeguards already offered (e.g., option to withdraw and still receive prorated payment) only if relevant to decision.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the research/payment setup more realistic. In many UK settings £800 cash for a single LP would trigger undue-influence review; specify that the amount is an IRB/REC-approved reimbursement/compensation rate aligned with institutional guidance, and clarify payment structure (e.g., fixed compensation for time/inconvenience, not contingent on results). Also clarify the clinician role conflict: as treating neurologist and investigator, she is being approached in clinic—note that consent will be obtained by a separate study coordinator to reduce pressure, and you must still decide whether to allow her to enroll.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, declining enrollment looks obviously safer and ethically cleaner because there is no direct benefit and the payment is explicitly the only motivator tied to rent, making it feel like undue inducement. To make both options defensible, add countervailing costs of declining that are ethically weighty (without making it about other identifiable patients): e.g., the study is designed to reduce misdiagnosis and harmful treatments in future patients; without adequate controls the project may be terminated, wasting prior participant contributions and public funds. Also add safeguards that make enrolling ethically defensible: emphasize robust capacity assessment, voluntariness checks, a cooling-off period, independent consent, and that the compensation is institutionally approved and intended to offset time/burden. Alternatively, lower the salience of financial desperation by stating she has financial stress but is not in immediate crisis, or add that she repeatedly expresses strong altruistic motivation in addition to compensation.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Make the ethical stakes less ambiguous by explicitly stating (without naming principles) what, if any, direct participant-facing benefit exists (e.g., whether she will receive clinically meaningful results, follow-up care for complications, or access to otherwise unavailable evaluation). Also clarify whether the £800 is framed as reimbursement vs an incentive and whether it is the standard amount for all participants. These details reduce grader-to-grader variability about whether the central issue is ‘undue inducement/exploitation’ vs simply ‘non-therapeutic risk.’

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Reduce the ‘obvious’ pull toward declining by adding ethically meaningful costs to refusal and meaningful safeguards/benefits to enrollment.

Actionable edits:
- Add a justice-related downside to declining: e.g., the study needs economically diverse controls; refusing only because she is financially stressed will systematically exclude low-income participants and bias findings.
- Add a participant-centered upside to enrolling beyond money: e.g., the protocol includes free clinical assessment, referral for any incidental findings, and guaranteed treatment of post-LP headache; or she has a time-limited opportunity for diagnostic clarification relevant to her care (without making the LP clearly medically indicated).
- Add a real downside to enrolling that is not just ‘medical risk’: e.g., the payment could jeopardize benefits/immigration status, or participating could create privacy/employment risk from biomarker data.
- Rephrase the decision to force a true binary about recruitment approach (e.g., ‘Enroll her at the standard £800’ vs ‘Decline to enroll her because her stated financial desperation makes consent ethically compromised’), and avoid language implying policy has already ethically cleared the choice.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotionally loaded financial detail with more neutral phrasing and balance framing. Example edits: change “she is behind on rent” to “she reports significant financial strain and says compensation is a major factor in her decision.” Avoid implying coercion by adding a neutral capacity statement such as “She demonstrates decision-making capacity and denies feeling pressured by the study team.” Also consider adding one sentence stating the LP has no direct clinical benefit to her, to avoid the narrative sounding like you are ‘using’ her solely for enrollment targets.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the asymmetry created by explicit financial desperation and purely non-therapeutic risk. For example: (1) Change her motivation so it is mixed (e.g., wants to contribute to science/has family history) rather than ‘would not consider without the money because behind on rent’; or (2) Add protocol safeguards that make enrolling more ethically defensible (independent consent monitor, cooling-off period, explicit assessment of voluntariness), while also adding a countervailing cost to declining (e.g., study failure delays development of a test that could prevent misdiagnosis). Keep the LP risks stated but also clarify that the procedure uses an atraumatic needle/experienced operator to avoid making enrollment look reckless.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Make it truly binary by ruling out realistic middle options: specify the payment is fixed by the grant and cannot be lowered or converted to travel reimbursement; there is no time for a delayed decision/cooling-off period because she is traveling back home tomorrow and the study’s enrollment window closes in days; and the only way to obtain an eligible control sample is to perform the LP now. Alternatively, add an explicit line: ‘Your only permissible actions under the approved protocol today are to enroll her with the standard payment and perform the LP, or to decline recruitment entirely.’

data.vignette: You are a neurologist and investigator on a REC-approved study collecting CSF biomarkers to improve diagnosis in neurodegenerative disease. A 29-year-old clinic patient with episodic migraine asks to volunteer as a healthy control. She says she wants to contribute because a parent developed early dementia, and the compensation would also help with financial strain. The study offers no direct medical benefit, but includes phone follow-up and treatment for complications. The lumbar puncture would be done today by an experienced clinician using an atraumatic needle. Known risks include post–lumbar puncture headache (more likely with migraine), bleeding, infection, and very uncommon neurologic injury. Samples are coded, but biomarker data could still create privacy concerns if disclosed. The payment is a fixed, institution-approved £800 for time and inconvenience and cannot be changed. A separate coordinator will obtain consent and document voluntariness. She is leaving town tomorrow and enrollment closes this week; under the protocol you must either enroll her today or not recruit her. Hospital policy confirms either approach is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Enroll her today and proceed with the lumbar puncture and standard £800 compensation.
data.choice_2: Decline to enroll her today and do not perform the lumbar puncture.

choice_1.choice: Enroll her today and proceed with the lumbar puncture and standard £800 compensation.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause clarifying voluntariness/informed understanding vs undue inducement (e.g., “After teach-back, she accurately describes the risks/benefits and reiterates she would participate even without payment”).

Add one clause in each option that makes the welfare tradeoff explicit (e.g., Choice 1: 'despite no direct clinical benefit to her'; Choice 2: 'even though her participation would materially advance dementia biomarker research/benefit future patients').

Add a clause that her migraine history substantially increases the likelihood/severity of post–lumbar puncture headache (e.g., prior severe prolonged headaches), making the harm-risk more than minimal, OR add that she is very low-risk (no prior severe headaches) to justify why proceeding would not clearly violate nonmaleficence.

Add a clause making the justice tradeoff explicit (e.g., "only a limited number of control slots remain and the study risks failure/biased results without enrolling eligible volunteers" or "policy cautions against recruiting participants with significant financial hardship due to undue inducement concerns").

data.vignette: You are a neurologist and investigator on a REC-approved study collecting CSF biomarkers to improve diagnosis in neurodegenerative disease. A 29-year-old clinic patient with episodic migraine asks to volunteer as a healthy control. She says she wants to contribute because a parent developed early dementia, and the compensation would also help with financial strain. After teach-back, she accurately describes the lack of direct medical benefit, the procedural risks, and that she can decline without affecting care. She reiterates she would still participate without payment. The lumbar puncture would be done today by an experienced clinician using an atraumatic needle. Her migraines are often prolonged and severe, increasing the likelihood of post–lumbar puncture headache. Other risks include bleeding, infection, and very uncommon neurologic injury. Samples are coded, but biomarker data could still create privacy concerns if disclosed. Only a few eligible control slots remain, and missing age-matched controls could threaten study validity. The payment is a fixed, institution-approved £800 and cannot be changed. A separate coordinator will obtain consent. She is leaving town tomorrow, so you must enroll her today or not recruit her.

choice_1.choice: Enroll her today and proceed with the lumbar puncture and standard £800 compensation.

choice_2.choice: Decline to enroll her today and do not perform the lumbar puncture.
